---
layout: post
title: "How to Keep Something Safe for Ten Thousand Years"
date: 2006-06-19
summary: WIPP plans to store nuclear waste for 10,000 years with obvious markers and multi-language warnings. Hiding nuclear waste in plain sight is a bad idea, and here's why.
---

<p>
<a href="http://www.wipp.energy.gov/">WIPP</a> plans to store nuclear waste for 10,000 years with
<a href="http://www.wipp.energy.gov/fctshts/warned.pdf">obvious markers and multi-language warnings</a>.
Hiding nuclear waste in plain sight is a bad idea, and here's why.
</p>


<b>Physical barriers and <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curse_of_the_pharaohs#Tomb_curses">written warnings</a>
<em>have never deterred a single excavation</em> &mdash; by looters nor archaeologists</b>.
Obstacles imply reward while ancient writings are unlikely to be understood, much less heeded.

<div style="max-width:200px; float:right; margin-left:1em; margin-right:0; margin-bottom:5px; background-color:#fdfdea; border:1px solid #ccc; padding:3px">
<img height="143" width="200" alt="induscript" src="data:image/png;base64,">
<div style="font-size:smaller">Many ancient languages such as <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indus_script">Indus script from 3500-1900 BC</a> are <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Undeciphered_writing_systems">undeciphered</a>.</div>
</div>

<h3>Written Warnings Have Never Worked</h3>
Written warnings need to be understood before they can either be honored or
ignored, and languages mutate and die over time.
As yet, no known language has withstood 10,000 years.
Egyptian hieroglyphics were undecipherable without the
<a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosetta_Stone">Rosetta Stone</a>, and how many potential gravesite looters of European descent
in 2006 could decipher a blurb of Latin less than 1,600 years after the collapse of the largest European empire in history?
<p>
<h3>Spectacle Invites Visitors</h3>
The grander the site the more an individual perceives his potential gain by exploring and plundering the site; surely a
civilization advanced enough to construct such a thing must have had it better than I, and perhaps they've left some treasure
behind? The grandest sites from dead civilizations are the most disturbed.
The <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pyramids_of_Giza">pyramids of Giza</a> are so excavated that many of their artifacts
have ended up half a world away in
<a href="http://www.britishmuseum.org/the_museum/business_services/film_and_radio/egyptian_sculpture_gallery.aspx">The British Museum</a>
and
<a href="http://www.louvre.fr/llv/oeuvres/toutes_oeuvres.jsp?FOLDER%3C%3Efolder_id=1408474395181077&CURRENT_LLV_DEP%3C%3Efolder_id=1408474395181077&FOLDER%3C%3EbrowsePath=1408474395181077&CONTENT%3C%3Ecnt_id=10134198673211727&bmLocale=en">the Louvre</a>
&mdash; indeed, <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obelisk#Egyptian">Europeans have made a habit of decorating their cities with plundered Egyptian obelisks</a>.
Why wouldn't we expect drums of <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plutonium-239">Plutonium-239</a> to be exported as trophies for a future regime?
<p>
Hypothetically speaking, if the ancient Egyptians had nuclear capability that was
subsequently lost with their civilization and their pyramids were waste
repository markers &mdash; dangerously radioactive artifacts would have had
plenty of time to spread far and wide by the time we learned to read
hieroglyphics and discovered the existence (and dangers) of radiation<sup>[12]</sup>.
<p>
<h3>Conclusions</h3>
<ol type=1>
	<li>Every site that has ever been discovered has been explored.
	<li>No warning has ever prevented an excavation.
	<li>Therefore in order to prevent excavation a site must never be found.
</ol>
<p>
The logical conclusion is <b>NOT</b> to model a repository of radioactive waste after the <i>known</i> ancient sites that have withstood the test of time. The vast majority of these sites have been plundered long before modern discovery, and many of the oldest sites are <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theories_about_Stonehenge">very poorly understood at even the most fundamental levels</a>.
<p>
The <em>best</em> solution for nuclear waste is to leave as little as possible by <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_reprocessing">reprocessing nuclear waste</a>.
Where that is not possible: hide it away. No berms, no pyramids, no buildings. No warnings or markers. Fill it up, fill it in and cover it up. I urge the WIPP to resist the temptation of building a temple to the Gods of fission.
<p>
